importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when President Donald Trump is scheduled to meet with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky at the White House, and when the update on the potential deployment of Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine was published.

Two months prior to the latest developments, Trump and Putin met in Alaska, and this meeting is referenced as a point in time when the possibility of a peace agreement was first discussed, though outcomes were unclear.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This timeframe marks the period just before the scheduled Trump-Zelensky meeting, during which Putin made a last-ditch attempt to prevent the discussion of sending Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine.

keyTakeAways: President Donald Trump has not ruled out sending Tomahawk cruise missiles to Ukraine, even after his meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin.
Trump reportedly said during a conversation with Putin that he would give 'a couple thousand Tomahawks' to Ukraine’s opposition, indicating a willingness to consider such a move.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and his aides view the Tomahawk missiles as a game-changing tool that could pressure Russia into negotiating a peace deal.
Putin opposed the idea, arguing that the missiles would damage the US-Russia relationship and that they would not meaningfully impact the battlefield due to their range and operational constraints.
US officials suggest Trump is using the threat of missile delivery as a diplomatic leverage tool to push for a peace settlement, not necessarily as an immediate military action.
The possibility of escalation remains a concern among US officials, though some argue past escalatory actions have not significantly intensified the conflict.
Trump is expected to refrain from committing to sending the weapons during his meeting with Zelensky, though the option remains open and could be activated if he decides it is appropriate.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The 47th President of the United States, who is currently in negotiation with Russia and Ukraine regarding military support and peace initiatives.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Trump is central to the discussion of sending Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine, and his statements to Putin and Zelensky are key to understanding the diplomatic and military dynamics of the situation.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Putin
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The President of Russia, who engaged in a phone call with Donald Trump and expressed opposition to the idea of sending Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Putin's resistance to the missile proposal highlights the geopolitical tension and risk of escalation between Russia and the United States, and underscores the strategic stakes of the conflict.

namedEntities.name: Volodymyr Zelensky
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The President of Ukraine, who has expressed strong interest in receiving Tomahawk cruise missiles as a deterrent against Russian aggression.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Zelensky’s advocacy for the missiles is tied to his broader goal of pressuring Putin into negotiations, making him a key stakeholder in the potential military escalation or peace deal.

namedEntities.name: Tomahawk cruise missiles
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Long-range American-made cruise missiles with a range exceeding 1,000 miles, capable of targeting major Russian cities such as Moscow and St. Petersburg.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: These missiles are seen as a potential turning point in the war, and their potential deployment is at the center of diplomatic negotiations between the US, Ukraine, and Russia.

namedEntities.name: United States
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The country that has the capability to supply Tomahawk missiles and is involved in diplomatic negotiations with both Ukraine and Russia.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The US is the source of the missiles and the primary actor in the political and military balancing act that could lead to a shift in the conflict’s trajectory.

namedEntities.name: Russia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The country currently at war with Ukraine and a key opponent in the conflict, which is central to the discussion around missile deployment and peace negotiations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Russia's opposition to the Tomahawk deployment illustrates its fear of escalation and its strategic concerns about US military involvement in the war.

namedEntities.name: Ukraine
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The country currently under attack from Russia and seeking military support from the United States.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Ukraine is the recipient of the proposed Tomahawk missiles, and its leadership sees them as a critical tool for achieving peace through strategic deterrence.

summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump has not ruled out sending long-range Tomahawk cruise missiles to Ukraine, despite a recent meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin, who opposed the idea and warned it would damage US-Russia relations. While Trump expressed interest in providing the weapons during a conversation with Putin, he is not expected to commit to sending them during his upcoming meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky. Ukrainian officials view the missiles as a game-changing deterrent capable of pressuring Russia into negotiations. The US administration has prepared plans to deploy the weapons if Trump decides, emphasizing that the threat serves as a diplomatic leverage tool rather than an immediate military action. Concerns over escalation remain, though some officials believe prior escalatory steps have not significantly intensified the conflict. A call between Putin and Trump just 24 hours before the Ukraine meeting was intended to delay the discussion, but Trump maintained his stance on the possibility of sending the missiles, indicating ongoing high-stakes negotiations between the world’s major powers.
title: Trump hasn’t closed the door on sending Tomahawk missiles to Ukraine
